neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: I do not like football because it is boring. When do you usually buy food during your day? Are there tasty plant-based options you could try the next time you have a choice?

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.\n\nA year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.\n\nStay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.\n\nClimate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.\n\nYou can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: Hi panda, I am sloth.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Hi funky panda, I am dreamy sloth

neutral_message: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: It is nice to meet you.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Nice to meet you 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Do you like or love football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Do you like or love football 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I enjoy watching football.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I love watching football

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,\nand the corresponding sentences written without any style.\nYour task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.\n\nThe text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.\n\nFor conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. \n Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). \nReturn results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} \n#####\nHere is an example sentence written without any style: It is nice to meet you.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Nice to meet you 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Do you like or love football?\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Do you like or love football 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I enjoy watching football.\nHere is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I love watching football

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Fruits and vegetables are filled with important nutrients like vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that help our bodies fight diseases. For instance, people who eat mostly plant foods were 39% less likely to get Covid and have fewer hospital visits overall.\n\nEvery time we buy food ourselves, we get to decide what goes into our bodies. To make it more fun, you could also talk with your friends during lunch and try out some plant-based foods together.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.

Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. neutral_message: 80% of young people believe that living sustainably is very important for their happiness. And 77% say they would choose meat alternatives as part of their sustainable lifestyle.\n\nIt's good to see how much our generation agrees on this. Even if we're not trying to be completely vegan, each of us can do something to help. For example, we can try the plant-based food options in our school cafeteria or some meat alternatives more often.

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.\n\nA year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.\n\nStay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.\n\nClimate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.\n\nYou can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Fiber is really important for keeping our stomachs healthy, and it's only found in plants, not in animal foods. When we have enough fiber in our meals, we stay full for longer and have more energy throughout the school day, avoiding that tired feeling after lunch.\n\nChanging our habits, like what we eat, can be tricky at first. An easy way to start could be to try more plant-based lunches at school to feel more energetic and ready for the afternoon.

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

  "rewritten_sentence": "Hey! Cheers for following along for the first week! 😄

I'm pretty stoked to see more people choosing plant-based eating. Some of my fav celebs are vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, mostly avoid animal products.

Plus, I'm seeing new plant-based products and restaurants popping up everywhere. Looks like we'll have loads of options in the future! 🧐

Why not check if some of your fav celebs are into plant-based too?",
  "explanation": "I've added informal language and contractions to match person X's style, such as 'Cheers' for thanks, 'stoked' for excited, and 'loads' for lots. I've also included emoticons as person X uses them. I've maintained the use of first-person perspective and kept the sentence structure relatively short and simple, mirroring the provided examples. The length of the rewritten text is within the allowed +-25% deviation."
}
query:
You are an expert in text style transfer. You will be given few examples sentences of a conversational style of person X,
and the corresponding sentences written without any style.
Your task is to learn the conversational style of person X, and rewrite a target text without any style to a text with a conversational style of person X.

The text length of the newly created target text cannot deviate more than +-25% from the original target text.

For conversational style please consider 1. how person X uses function words (e.g., pronouns such as "I", "we", "you"), 2. which tone person X prefers (e.g., formal/informal vs. analytical vs. narrative), and 3. often used stylistic words (e.g., phrases, fillers words), 4. emoji or emoticon-use in the provided example sentences and 5. other stylistic characteristics you find.Please only add words/phrases/fillers/emoticons/emojis that person X explicitly uses in the example sentences. 
 Only add any variations of ‘haha’ if appropriate (in a humorous context.)"). 
Return results in a json object as {"rewritten_sentence": "", "explanation": ""} 
#####
Here is an example sentence written without any style: What do you not like about football?
Here is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: what don’t you like about football?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Is it the running, the teams, or is it not your thing at all?
Here is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X:  Is it the running, the teams, or just not your thing at all? 🧐"

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Do you enjoy playing football, or do you find it boring?
Here is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Fair enough, but what about playing football? Do you enjoy kicking a ball around with mates, or is that boring too?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I understand. Do you think you would be good at playing it, even if you do not like watching? Like scoring goals or being a goalkeeper?
Here is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Alright, I get that! But you reckon you'd be good at playing it, even if you don't like watching? Like scoring goals or being in goal?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I am good. I like football quite a bit—it is fun to play with friends and watch big matches. What about you? Are you into any sports?
Here is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I'm good, cheers! 😄 I like football quite a bit—it’s fun to play with mates and watch big matches. What about you? Are you into any sports?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I support Liverpool. Do you support any team or are you not interested in it?
Here is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Liverpool, of course!  What about you? Do you support anyone, or not into it?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Not everyone is interested in sports. What do you enjoy doing instead? Do you have any interesting hobbies?
Here is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: Fair enough! Not everyone’s into sports. What do you like doing instead? Any cool hobbies or things you’re into? 

Here is an example sentence written without any style: Why do you not like football?
Here is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: What’s up with not liking football?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: I enjoy football as it is entertaining to play with friends, with exciting events such as goals and passes, and it helps maintain an active lifestyle. However, I understand that it may not appeal to everyone. What activities do you enjoy?
Here is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I like football because it’s fun to play with friends, and there’s always something exciting happening, like goals and good passes! It’s also a good way to stay active. But I get it, it’s not for everyone. What do you do for fun instead?

Here is an example sentence written without any style: The dog is bouncy.
Here is the example sentence rewritten in the style of person X: I think bouncy dog



#####

Here is a target text written without any style {Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based? }
Here is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

Here is a target text written without any style {Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Vegetables and fruits have helpful plant substances that support our brain health and help it work well. To start, you could challenge yourself, your friends, or your parents to have more plant-based meals on some days of the week (with an occasional cheat day here and there).

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.\n\nClimate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.\n\nYou can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Animal farming is responsible for 80% of the loss of the Amazon rainforest because farmers need space for cattle and cattle food. Last year, the Amazon rainforest lost as many trees as there are in the UK and Ireland combined. Imagine if there were not a single tree left here!\n\nBy eating less meat (like choosing veggie burgers instead of regular burgers for lunch), we can make a difference without needing to change much. If you eat with others, you can also set an example and inspire your friends and classmates, to be more mindful about their food choices as well.

Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

\n#####\n\nHere is a target text written without any style {More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.}\nHere is the target text rewritten in the conversational style of person X: {\n\n\n

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.

neutral_message:
Hello! I’m Sasha, nice to meet you! Over the next two weeks, I will explore healthy and sustainable eating with you.

A year ago, I started eating more plant-based foods and learned a lot along the way. It’s not about being perfect; I don’t think we all need to go completely vegan. However, being a bit mindful of how much animal food we eat and drink can be good for our health and the planet.

Stay tuned, as I will share lots of interesting science facts and give you tips for small changes that can make a big difference.

neutral_message:
Hey! Thanks for following along for the first week.

I'm excited to see how more people are choosing plant-based eating. Some of my favourite celebrities eat vegan, like Lewis Hamilton, Billie Eilish, and Ariana Grande. Others, like Harry Styles and Lionel Messi, avoid animal products for the most part.

I also see new plant-based products and restaurants appearing everywhere.  It looks like we'll have lots of options in the future!

Why not see if some of your favorite celebrities also eat plant-based?

neutral_message: Reducing how much meat we eat can help save a lot of CO2, which causes climate change. For example, if we eat meat every other day instead of every day for a year, it saves as much CO2 as driving a car from London to China… and back!\n\nWith small changes like this, everyone can help the environment and slow down climate change now without waiting for others! Let’s start small;  for example, we can try to eat meat only once a day, instead of having it at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

neutral_message:
If everyone ate less animal foods, the CO2 from food production would drop by 68%. Just by changing our food choices, we could be halfway to stopping climate change.

Climate change will mostly affect us young people because we will see its outcomes in our lifetime. Instead of being cynical, let's look for small, effective changes that we can make right now. Choosing more plant-based meals or snacks when possible is one of the easiest things we can do.

You can also find out which foods are especially harmful for to climate (hint: the farm animal that is worst for the climate rhymes with ‘wow’).

neutral_message: More than 70% of farm animals in the UK are raised on factory farms to keep animal products cheap. On these farms, a chicken has only about the space of a laptop, so there's hardly any room to move. It's like living under a staircase, like Harry Potter, for your whole life.\n\nFactory farms keep going because people buy their products. By choosing to eat less meat or plant-based meats when we can, we can send a message to these farms to make better living conditions for their animals.

neutral_message: Most pigs and chickens in the UK are kept indoors their whole lives and never see sunlight. Animals that can't go outside are more stressed and, scientists say, much less happy.\n\nWe may not be able to change how animals are treated on these farms directly. But we can choose more vegetables and meat alternatives (like plant-based schnitzel, sausages, and burgers) instead of animal meat. This is the quickest way to help make animals' lives better.
